headline: Democratic presidential rivals turn on Mike Bloomberg
subHeadline: Former New York City Mayor Mike Bloomberg's past comments, policies spark outrage; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Emily Compagno, Donna Brazile, Jesse Watters, and Greg Gutfeld. It is 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." Another jam-packed week of 2020 politics as President Trump threatens to overshadow Democrats yet again. The president is up for a big Las Vegas rally the day before the Nevada caucuses, which are on Saturday.  And instead of putting their full focus on Trump, 2020 Democrats, they're going after each other, this time setting their sights on Michael Bloomberg and his campaign spending.

utterances.speaker: AMY KLOBUCHAR (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: He just can't hide behind the airways. He has to answer questions.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: Sixty billion dollars can buy you a lot of advertising. But it can't erase your record. There's a lot to talk about Michael Bloomberg.

utterances.speaker: ELIZABETH WARREN (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: -- democracy. No one should be able to buy an election.

utterances.speaker: BERNIE SANDERS (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: Well, I got news for Mr. Bloomberg. And that is the American people are sick and tired of billionaires buying elections.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And Bloomberg's past comments continue to cause problems. Rivals say Bloomberg is insulting hardworking farmers, saying resurface video (ph). But his campaign responding by saying Bloomberg's comments are being taken out of context. And he was contrasting thousands of years of farming with today's technology-driven workplace. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL BLOOMBERG (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: If you think about the agrarian society, it lasted 3,000 years. And we can teach processes. I can teach anybody, even people in this room, so no offense intended to be a farmer. It's a process. You dig a hole. You put a seed in. You put dirt on top. Add water, up comes the corn.   Then, you have 300 years of the industrial society. You put the piece of metal on the leaf (ph) you turn the crank in the direction of the arrow and you can have job (ph).

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Bloomberg also making news today after his campaign pushed back on a report that he would consider Hillary Clinton as his vice presidential pick. I think that was not true. Jesse, do you think that that was true?

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Do you think Hillary Clinton's people put that out there?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He needs a food tester. I don't know if I would trust Hillary as my VP. She'd be right after every move he made. I think that was just a leak to drudge to get some media out of the weekend. But she's got so much baggage. He needs someone young and energetic and crooked doesn't come to mind when you think about that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And also they can't be both from New York.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I did not know that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's interesting. I learned a lot of interesting things about Mike Bloomberg this weekend. You know, he's been nasty to women and to blacks and to seniors and to farmers. But I did not know that he puts ice in his beer, which is pure psychopath.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- if you are a billionaire --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I guess you can, but --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And the question is -- bottom line, do any of these Democrats out there, are they talented enough to capitalize on all these ridiculous things coming out of the Bloomberg campaign? My answer is no. They're just -- this is not strong enough and they are all too weak. The guy has got no message. What is his message? I'm richer and nicer than Donald Trump?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He says Mike can get it done.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Mike can get it done. What is it? What is the it that Mike can get done? Mike's not even running his campaign. He's not -- he's just cutting checks. He's not even dictating the tweets.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And everyone is getting rich off of the campaign.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But his numbers are going up, Donna.

utterances.speaker: DONNA BRAZILE, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Don't worry about Michael Bloomberg. First of all --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Do I look worried, Donna?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Yes, baby, I can see you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This is not the face of worry.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Baby, you are sweating because when you first start describing this man, I thought you were talking about Donald Trump. Because by the way, Michael Bloomberg is a former Republican, I first came to know him when he spoke the 2004 Republican convention here in New York.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: That is correct. You know what? And now, he's running. Now, let me just -- Dana asked a good question. His so-called slogan is Mike will bring decency, respect, and something else back to the White House.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Something else. OK, it doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: It gets blurry. All right, so here's the thing. Michael Bloomberg is running a two-track campaign. The first track is to get people like us to talk about him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Right? And the second track is to get people like us to vote for him. Now, on the first track, we are succeeding. We are talking about it. The second track, I don't think he's going to do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I agree.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: OK. Now, that's it. Can we talk about something else?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Michael Bloomberg has a long career, as a lot of these -- especially if you are in your 70s and you're running. You have a long career. You've done a lot of things. You've probably gone to a lot of events. And I imagine that they are going to drop these little videos about Michael Bloomberg.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Tasteful erotic photography in his past.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I was going to defend him until you told me about the ice cubes. Now, I don't know what to do. Look, this whole thing of this outrage, if the outrage is too easy, it's out of context, which means almost all outrage about comments and quotes are always out of context. And I defended it with people I like. And I will defend it with Bloomberg, who I'm kind of indifferent towards. But I would say that if, like, if you examine the statement that he made, it's in an audience that understands the statement. And when you take it under context, it means something else. So I'm going to take a statement that he made that now everybody is saying is really bad. So in 2011, he said that there is an enormous cohort of young black and Latino men who don't know how to behave in the workplace.  All right, that's sounds terrible. Everybody is talking about it. But then the context is he was speaking to PBS, while introducing $127 million program to help minority guides get jobs. So what he was saying was how do you -- why is that program necessary, because there's an issue. And so he explains why there is an issue and he's trying to remedy the issue. So it's not fair to anybody when you -- right, left, middle, to keep to keep pulling these things out. The problem with the Democrats is -- or the left, actually, not -- they can't pass their own standards anymore, because you have a pocket of intersectional activists who think everybody is oppressed or -- and you are the oppressor.  So they are applying today's -- I said this on Friday, they're applying today's standards to decisions that one makes in the past. And you can't do that.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: And the other thing, Greg, to your point, because I agree with you half the time, as you well know, to your point, back in the day, stop and frisk, before it was ruled unconstitutional, was a practice not just here in New York but other lower cities. So let's just get that straight.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: True.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: And Donald Trump made a speech before the police chiefs in 2018, where he said it was a good policy. It was a bad policy. You know why? Because you stop people who were in innocent just because of their skin color. By the way, I can't get rid of this. I may get rid of this, OK? Just because of your skin color, you are pulling people aside. And you're -- and that was ruled unconstitutional.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Can I respond to this? Because there are two points, it was originally called stop, question, and frisk. That's the first mistake because you're questioned, the cop makes an observation. But no one ever mentions the question part. Number two, before stop and frisk, people would complain, activists and politicians and media would complain, that people only care about crimes if it happens to a white person. Hence, the missing white girl gets attention but the black boys in Atlanta didn't, the young black boys that -- so that was a big criticism. So New York City decides we are going to focus on minority neighborhoods and get the crime out of there. That's racist, too. So if you focus, you are racist. And if you don't care, you are racist. So you can't win.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: During the peak of the crime epidemic in this country, many innocent people were pulled over, questioned, stopped, simply because of the way they look. And that's why it's good to talk about the policy and just not make it about the personality.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So let's get Emily in here about maybe on -- whatever you want to talk about. But I was thinking about then the Bloomberg's side of things. It is like -- Donna's point of we are all talking about him, but really the Democrats are all talking about him, because you are trying to buy this election.

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Right. And it remains to be seen how many people don't care about that, because they say the only thing that matters is beating Donald Trump at the ballot box. I think what it's interesting about the -- all of the years that we are looking back on Bloomberg, is that yes, when you isolate the comments. You can either defend them or somehow explain them away, which a lot of people on his behalf are doing. But I think when you stand back and look at the trend. It belies that demeaning attitude or simply the selfish attitude that up until now, the entire Democratic Party was saying that they were trying to get away from.  They didn't want another New York, self-centered, narcissistic, you know, fly over country hating person. And that's exactly what this person is representing himself to be in all of those video clips and the book about him and everything. It's not just one comment where you're, like, OK, is that enough. There is a ton that sort of belie that type of I'm better than you personality, infirming and everything. And I think it's interesting what Klobuchar said, which is look, you are beating us in the ads, sure. But you are not going to beat us on the stage. And I think it's really going to be fascinating to finally see him on the stage and see whether, for example, his now explanation of the stop and frisk, his first class seat on the --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- it will be a big pile-on. Donna, is he in the debate? Is that announced yet?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I think they are waiting on one more poll.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're waiting for a box.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Where's the box?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: No. Stop that, you guys. That is not fair.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- I can make short jokes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, coming up, the media turn Michael Avenatti into a big cable news star. But now after his conviction, will there be any self reflection? Greg's monologue on that next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Some are calling it a first ever for CNN, no, not a ratings win. Dream on. In front of an audience, you can count on your fingers and toes one anchor gave this moment of self reflection.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I thought Avenatti could be a serious candidate for president. So give me a media critique. Was that stupid on my part? What do you make of how Avenatti was covered by CNN and MSNBC?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, if you have to ask, now that Mikey's been found guilty of extortion about to go on trial for other crimes and fuel the most heinous smears of Brett Kavanaugh, I think the answer is yes. You were stupid. And that's putting it lightly. Because this mea culpa should have happened a while ago before all the montages, of hacks kissing Avenatti's butt had forced your hand. And what if he hadn't been found guilty? If he had walked, it would have been right into CNN's open arms. But I should stop. I'm being a jerk. See, I could self-reflect, too. True to the max (ph) and that you should never mock someone for doing the right thing. I say good job, Brian, and you too, Toobin.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The total collapse of his life is really sort of extra -- and frankly, you know, I feel kind of snookered, because I took him seriously.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Snookered means you were unfairly tricked, that you were the victim. But Jeff, why were you fooled when everyone beyond the media wasn't? Was it because you wanted to believe Mikey had the goods on Trump and Kavanaugh? No matter how absurd those goods were, the media's excuse was that Avenatti was a part of the Stormy story.  No, they were looking for a savior, not a stripper. After all, where is their spotlight now? So the media got snookered because like a remote tribe thinking an empty Coke bottle falling from the sky came from the gods, their desperation made them credulous. So hooray for self reflection, but remember these suckers just spent three years calling you suckers for supporting the president. So see this as a rare moment. They will be back on that horse in no time, leaving a trail of manure wherever they go, which makes it an easy story to follow. All right, Donna, you agree with me on everything I just said, don't you?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I'm --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But why is it so hard for the media to self reflect?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Look, the media should. We all should. That's what institutions should do. Look, Michael Avenatti came to the DNC meeting back in 2019. He came for my vote and the votes of other Democrats. And many of us looked him up, looked him down. He always wore nice suits just like you, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not that night.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: This ain't no off direct quality. I just touched and I'm still bleeding. What Michael Avenatti was a scam artist.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Put it that way, OK. I hope he gets a fair trial in California. But this guy got over $175 million worth of free media.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yup.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Defending Stormy Daniels, going out there with some other person.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I -- speaking of free media, you just helped -- I want to play some free media. And you guys all comment on it. This is more of the obsession with Avenatti.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I think that Mueller is not going to take Trump down. I think that Avenatti is going to take Trumped down.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Because Donald Trump is terrified of Michael Avenatti.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: -- to me, you're like the Holy Spirit. You're like all praises at all times.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Michael Avenatti for president in 2020?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He is Donald Trump's worst nightmare, Michael Avenatti.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So I don't know who to call on for this one, the Holy Spirit, anybody?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'll take it. I think it's always important. I always like to question the -- if there is a lot of hype about something, like if it's a movie or a novel, I always want to wait just a minute. Like, tap the breaks. Let other people kick the tires before I would, like, jump in, because something like this could happen. And he did have scam artist --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- in a nice suit.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Emily, you're a lawyer. This guy makes your profession look disgusting. I look at you differently.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: I think what is so -- I have so many troubling aspects about this, one of them being, you know, the total collapse of his life, how it's extraordinary. The total collapse doesn't happen overnight. That's like when you hear about a celebrity or a star, and they're like no, that was 10 years of them sleeping in their car and going on auditions 24 hours a day. So you don't get to a 36-count federal indictment without years of preparation on the federal government's part. He hasn't paid taxes since 2010. So the notion -- and this doesn't include, by the way --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The multiple lawsuits --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: How do you do that?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: And, you know, there multiple lawsuits by his clients as well. So all of that is not only discoverable but it's obvious. So that's number one. So the fact is that this is like oh, we had no idea, all it does is speak volumes about them, not him.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: He should've been vetted. And just likewise, we need to vet cabinet members. We need to vet people in general. That's why we're vetting Michael Bloomberg, OK? I mean, we have to vet --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We know Bloomberg. We knew Trump. We didn't know this guy, which leads me to my big question is he -- do these guys have any excuse for saying we were snookered?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Permission to make an analogy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Absolutely, granted.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The media's like the guy at a bar that falls in love with a prostitute, right? Everybody at the bar knows that she's a prostitute. And they are all laughing and they're all warning the guy. But the guy thinks he's in love. And the other thing they have a connection. And no one really believes there's a connection there.  And he goes upstairs, she takes his money. He has a good time. But you know what? He learns nothing from it. And he does it again the next month. And this is what happens in the media. It's not just Avenatti. It's the dossier. It's Smollett. It's Covington. I mean, they fell for Beto. They think global warming is going to kill us in 12 years. These people are all marks. And they get taken advantage of by the CIA, by leakers, by politicians, by lobbyists. If they had the same agenda as you, they would just buy the media up and then they are gone the next day.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Waiting in the waters.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I might have held your hand on that one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The media is being used and they kind of like it.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: People get pimped all the time. You talk about prostitutes. This was a pimp.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, who is running Michael?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Interesting. You know what? We have more of this scintillating conversation. Coming up next, former journalist throw their support behind Bloomberg, but will it backfire? That's next.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Retired ABC news anchor, Sam Donaldson, yes, he's my friend, is jumping to politics and he is endorsing Mike Bloomberg.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I think Mike Bloomberg is best suited to take on Donald J. Trump this November and beat him. And that's something I think is very important for the country. We are in the grip, Anderson, of a sick, ignorant man. He is mean. He is corrupt. And if we don't get this right, we may lose the things that have made this country the best place to live in the world.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Wait a minute. There is more. Former CBS anchor, Katie Couric, said this, and she is also my friend.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Let me ask everybody about this race and Michael Bloomberg. First of all, he was insulting Trump the other day.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my god. It was so amazing, wasn't it? Trump is like a heat-seeking missile. He can latch to your vulnerabilities. And Bloomberg, I think in that one tweet, Donald Trump hates that his back was turned. You know that all the New York maccas (ph) turned their back on him.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my god. All my friends are just jumping on board the Bloomberg train. You know, I better just go ahead and get myself a helicopter and fly right over there. Now, you know, we all know that celebrity and media endorsements, they always occur. But this is a journalist. So Dana, I mean, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I mean, if you're not under 45, you might not remember Sam Donaldson. But if you were to take yourself back you know -- in my house, we watched all the news. We watched all the programs, all the Sunday shows like my dad and I would watch it. Debate it, loved it. And Sam Donaldson was one of those guys from back then. Katie Couric, I think -- I'm going to set that aside, because I do think that it's a little bit different. But Sam Donaldson was one of those people that when, like, the George H.W. Bush campaign, I'm going back to the President George H.W. 41, the first one. When they would complain about media bias, it was people like Sam Donaldson that would say how dare you accuse us of media bias. When Newsweek ran that -- the whimp cover about George H.W. Bush at the time and they complained about media bias, he's like, how dare you. We are journalists. We are fair and balanced. And I don't think that Sam Donaldson did the media any favors if they are worried about their credibility.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I don't think it matters.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm indignant anyway.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: They're nice on paper. And by the way, I just want to -- for the record, there are so many endorsements out there. Joe Biden, of course, George Martin, the creator of Games of Thrones, he endorsed Joe Biden. Michael Bloomberg, Judge Judy also --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Love her.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But Sam Donaldson is different.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Here's the deal. I'm not friends with either of them, so I don't care. Katie's problem is she was trying to be too current and too cool. And she did -- she fell for the same old mind-reading trick like she knows what Trump is thinking. No, she is completely gone. She doesn't know what she's talking about. The joke about Sam is that he said this is the first time in his career that he's made a political choice. How blind does he have to be not see his own bias or that flying squirrel that is sleeping on his head for the last 30 years?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, that ain't real. If that is real, he needs to shave it off and replace it with something else. But these are parallel blind spots, you see? If you can't see what's crazy on top of your head, you can't see what's crazy inside your head.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: First of all, I've known him for a long time. I will defend Sam Donaldson any day of the week. He's a wonderful person.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I will trash him every day.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: You're trashing him for what reason?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Just because I don't like -- I don't like schmoozey -- hey, I know this guy. I don't care. Screw him.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Did you read his statement? I thought it was a very clear, concise statement.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I can't hear him with that shiny thing on his head.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Listen. He's a newscaster. He's endorsing a guy that ordered his own news organization not to report on him, and that to report on any of the other Democrats. I mean, that's total hypocrisy. And think about it. We are now having the media endorse a billionaire who says mean things about women and says we need to throw blacks up against the wall and it's not Donald Trump. Seriously, it that where we are right now? This guy endorsed Scott Brown over Liz Warren. He endorsed George W. Bush over John Kerry. He has outspent Sanders, who spent the most by $400 million, $400 million, Donna. And the media's been saying we need to get money out of politics. There is this huge gap between the rich and the poor when you campaign finance. You can't buy elections. And the first billionaire that comes along and starts throwing money at Democrats and saying mean things about Trump, everybody starts gushing. Come on. You know how hypocritical this is.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Now, Michael Bloomberg knows Donald Trump in ways that many of us don't know Donald Trump. But look, let's go back to this celebrity endorsement. Emily, come on. You can't imagine John Legend endorsed Elizabeth Warren.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: And that's helped. I'm kidding. I mean, it hasn't helped. It doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She went right down.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: No. But that's my whole point. I mean, endorsements really don't matter. But I'm glad Sam has an opinion. He's a retired journalist and he's free to do what he wants to do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He should be retired.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Well, at 86, I hope we're retired too, babe.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That hair is only 20.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Not you. Not you. That hair is good, by the way. Like your hair. Go ahead, Emily. I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: No, it's OK. Yes, I think that those endorsements only work in the micro sense that if John Legend were to host a celebrities-only dinner with access to E. Warren in Hollywood at 25 grand a plate, sure, go ahead. And otherwise, all it is, is exhausting and disappointing. It's like earlier today, when I was looking at this new favorite author of mine, I'm like, oh, yes, I want to see if she's on social media and follow her. And then the first thing I saw was a very disappointing political tweet to me -- to in my opinion, and I was like damn. Like not you too.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right. And so --

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: What did you do?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes, what -- and then this -- what else I want to say is that similar to what we talked about a moment ago, that all this does is speak volumes about those journalists and not the candidate that they're trying to endorse. So with Sam Donaldson saying, he understands people. Really? Like that's the phrase you're going to use after 30 years of being quiet about it? That's what you think is actually going to make me be like, oh, he does, I'm going to vote for him. All it does is belied his idiocy in that moment.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: He's retired.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: And also the fact that there's a huge disconnect between those media figures and actual real people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: And with Katie Couric sitting there and being like, he's like a missile, and amazing, New York is not the center of the universe and there's a whole other country that feels disconnected by both who's running on the left, and also the media that is covering it.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: And let's just say this. Dave Chappelle was -- endorsed John -- I mean, Mr. Yang. Mr. Yang is out. Dave Chappelle, I'm sure Mr. Bloomberg is looking for you. Now. Zoom, zoom, President Trump has got a warm welcome at the Daytona 500. See it next on THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Daytona International Speedway, we love our country, and it's truly an honor to be with all of you at the great American race. Gentlemen, start your engines.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Thunderous applause and cheers for President Trump at the Daytona 500. The President and the First Lady arriving in style, flying over the racetrack on Air Force One before getting that rock star welcome. Trump also jumped into his limo they called The Beast to lead the warm-up lap. Of course, some in the liberal media hated it. Here's more from the president.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The tens of thousands of patriots here today have come for the fastest cars in the world-class motorsports. But NASCAR fans never forget that no matter who wins the race, what matters most is God, family, and country.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. All right, Emily, did you watch?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes, of course.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: OK. I love everything about this. I was so excited about this topic. When I cheered for the Raiders, there were so many people who when we would go out and do philanthropic things and community activities, that my -- their interaction with me was the one second that they might ever have in their whole lifetime, like touching essentially, the organization. And it was so important for me to be that appropriate ambassador and represent that organization because it was all larger than me. And that's how I felt about this. How incredible for the president to be at the Daytona 500, and to meet people and to be among people who don't live in D.C., who don't have that sort of everyday access that a lot of journalists do, who scoffed at this. And we saw a tweet by Maggie Haberman, right, and she was saying, using the official apparatus of the government for what appears to be a political event. No, you know what that was? The Beast is 22,000 pounds of badassery. And having our American president leading the NASCAR race, the biggest race of the season and meeting all of those --- we had Brian -- Clint Bowyer who was saying, you know, I judge people on how they treat me and others I'm with. And the President in that moment, shook my hand. He was nice to everyone. He took selfies with us. He did everything we wanted him to do. He was a regular guy who was excited about being there. So yesterday, I was 100 percent proud of my president, proud to love NASCAR, and I loved everything about it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Donna, you don't think that was abusive what the President did right?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Well, to use White House official funds. I mean, that's an issue that everyone -- whenever you use funds, that's --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Can he take an Uber?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Hold on a second. Maybe Lyft. I would have -- I would have given him a Lyft. I don't -- I don't major in the minors, and so -- I and I love sports. George W. Bush went, Ronald Reagan went. So let's have fun, folks. I'm not -- I'm not into that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. Good, good. I'm surprised to hear that.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: He went to the LSU Alabama games.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. He's been at baseball games, all presidents do sporting event.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Hold on. He went to LSU, Alabama, LSU won. He went to -- he went to the final game with Clemson, LSU won. As far as I'm concerned, every time he shows my team win.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. Except last time in 2016. What do you think, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, just from a communication standpoint in the White House, like it was masterfully done. And it was fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Except the rain delay.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. Nothing you can do about that. But you know, that actually meant you got two days out of it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And now, NASCAR, they're racing right now as I understand while we're on air.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Good point.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And whenever a president is running for reelection, there are complaints about this. Believe me, people were complaining about Barack Obama who was using official funds to go and do really fun things. But I love it. It doesn't matter. You got to -- you have to understand that if you're going to try to compete against him and he's running for reelection, he has all the trappings of the office that make it look better. So you have to -- you have to compensate for that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, he was -- yes, Barack Obama was filling out the brackets on ESPN with the Final Four. I mean, Greg was probably hating on him for that. But you know, I sit back and I realized, you know --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: How can you people ignore the elephant in the room, which is climate change. All those cars going around, the plane coming down and then the other car, disgusting. You know, the lesson here I think is what Emily brought up is in kind of like the mockery that there was a lot of bile on Twitter by the blue checkers towards the group at Daytona, not at the president, but at what they would call the toothless, the redneck, you know the deplorables. This is a thing that the Democrats have to get away from, which is you got to -- you got to stop damning groups because you're not going to win over any hearts by making fun of a massive group of people because they happen to like a certain sport. And I was -- I thought that was bad. But there's - - let's focus on the positive. The guy knows how to put on a show.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I mean, he knows -- and the thing is, if you know -- I think -- I think Donna knows the difference between show and the job. I think it drives people crazy when you can't tell the difference. Like never Trumpers get upset when they see this because they can't see the distinction between show and job, and it freaks them out. But when you see the show and that Trump is having a good time, people having a good time, so what it's fun. And he's good around everybody, man. He could do SNL, he can do Comedy Central, he can do this. I don't think Sanders can do this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, Sanders, they can't have NASCAR under Sanders. They want to get rid of gasoline. They're going to want a solar-powered cars driving around. It's not going to be that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Only in the daytime.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: By the way -- by the way, beer -- since we started the show with beer, beer drinkers are bipartisan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's true.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Not with ice, though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not with ice, Donna. The airline passenger on the receiving end of that seat punching video, already taking things to the next level. That's story coming up on the "FASTEST SEVEN."

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Totally amazing. Welcome back. Time for the "FASTEST SEVEN." First up, the woman in this viral video of a man punching her plane seat is fighting back, but is she going too far? Wendi, with an I, William says she is deciding whether to sue the man and American Airlines. Meanwhile, the CEO of Delta adding to the reclining seat debate. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: ED BASTIAN, CEO, DELTA
utterances.sentences: I think that the proper thing to do is if you're going to -- you're going to recline into somebody, that you ask if it's OK first and then you do it.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He should resign. OK, because he's in effect saying you don't get what you pay for. For example, if I buy a burger at McDonald's, I don't need permission to eat it at McDonald's. I paid for the burger, I could sit down and eat it, so he's wrong. But I have a solution. I have a solution for this. When you purchase that seat, you buy all the parts of the seat, right, because it's commerce. So why can't someone behind you pay you not to recline? And in fact, he would be purchasing that part of the chair from you. So maybe the person might say, hi, Dana, I'm sitting behind you. I'll buy all of your drinks. If you don't recline, or I'll give you this crisp $50 bill, and then you can decide. Isn't that the solution?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, if you have a crisp 50, you're not sitting in coach, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, 50 pesos.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: 50 pesos. I mean, as a valued gold medallion member, I understand what the CEO is saying. The proper thing to do instead of asking, I think you just put it down halfway. You don't go all the way back, but you don't stand up stiff. You go halfway back and call it a day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That is --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, some of them don't go halfway. And if you're short, I'm telling you, it is the worst because the seat pushes your head down, it's so annoying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I hate that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And the CEO is probably like 6'5, and doesn't know what it's like to be five-foot-tall.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He flies private.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: That's why I spend a lot of time on Southwest Airlines. Honestly, as "a frequent flyer," I am annoyed when people lower their back into my tray and my drink. And it's spill.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But they you lean back. Then you lean back. Everybody is --

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I never lean back. You know why? I don't want anybody smelling me, sniffing on me, like sitting this close.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Sniffing your hair? Who does that?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Who does that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Joe Biden does.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: But told be told, that guy was very annoying.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He was -- he was rude.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: He was rude.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He was not a gentleman. He was not raised right.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: And to your comment about commerce, Greg. The other day when I flew cross country on a different airline, and I saw that there were differently valued seats in the front which said, FYI, these seats do not recline, and so they were valued at less.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: So, therefore, if it plays into actual commerce, then we should be able to avail ourselves of it.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Spoken like a good lawyer.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Thank you. All right, next up, this may come as a surprise to some. More people died taking selfies than from shark attacks. Between 2011 and 17, over 250 people worldwide died taking their own pictures compared to just 50 who were killed by sharks.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: This doesn't surprise me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But you know how most people die? Taking selfies with the shark? That's how you really get killed.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Double trouble. I mean --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: These are called sui-selfies, sui-selfies. This is what happens when technology gets ahead of humanity, and we haven't figured it out yet. There's a crapload of traffic fatalities before they put in seatbelts. They let it happen. So this is like something that the humanity has all these smartphones and they're just abusing this and will catch up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: People should just learn to Photoshop themselves into the picture that they want and not die. You know what I mean?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh God, I got in trouble for that.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: That sounds like --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But the National Park Service does have a problem. Like they have to look like warn people, do not try to go out on this ledge and take a selfie.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's dangerous.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: I kind of love it. It's Darwin's natural selection. Yes, go out on that ledge. You're that dumb, you want to take a selfie? Bye. All right, finally, over 350 students have their dreams come true when they found out they got into the Mayo Clinic's Medical School. But it turns out it was a monumental mistake. An e-mail glitch caused the school to accidentally send acceptance letters to all applicants instead of just 46 who get it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, if I get cancer, I'm not going for treatment there because who knows who's treating me? I mean, these guys could have been like -- they could have been really reaching.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Those are different departments.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm not going to take that chance.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Hey, look, it could be worse than getting rejected by Mayo Clinic. You could get accepted by Chico State. I hate you, Chico. On you. Count it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Why do you hate --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because I rented my room at Berkeley to two students from Chico and they stole all my classic Sex Pistols posters and I haven't forgotten, you jerk. That was 1986.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Amazing.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Greg, what is -- what do you eat that allows you to be --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's what I don't eat.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: But look, I'm just going to say, if letter mailed tomorrow saying that I was accepted into medical school, I'm going to say return to sender. No way.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I mean, it's kind of nice to know that even in today's world, instead of basically just accepting all of them and say oh, our mistake, we'll just take you all for what was like a participation trophy, that there were consequences. That's typically doesn't happen anymore.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Sending -- people are sending them jars of mayo. I'm not kidding. I think I read that somewhere. Backcheck me, audience.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: I feel bad for that moment. I mean, can you imagine like that elation?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You're so excited and then you're not. I hate disappoint.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's a good lesson for life. You probably learned more in that moment than you did in four years of college. Looking forward to something and then having your dreams crushed, that's life.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: No, you got the acceptance letter and then you call the other school that -- and say, I'm not interested.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's true.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: That's bad business.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: All right, "ONE MORE THING" is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's time now for "ONE MORE THING." I'm going to show you something pretty cute. So, dogs are man's best friend, as we know, but also good opponents. Take a look at this dog playing a game.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You go, boy. You got it. You got it. Yes, good job.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What if he chokes on that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, that's Percy. He's a two-year-old cockapoo, and he was taught to play Connect the Four by his owner Sarah. She's a Toronto-based dog trainer. And as you can see, Percy is not great, but every once in a while he gets pretty lucky. And yes, as you see here, he wins. He wins one. He's pretty cute. I thought that's a nice way to start a Monday, don't you think?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes, I thought dogs were colorblind. That's so awesome that he can see the colors.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Oh my God.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Is that a -- oh, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I used to go to a bar called the cockapoo.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: How do you know a dog is colorblind?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: I don't know. Is that a myth?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You see how they dress in the morning.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse, you're next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. I was up in Vermont this weekend skiing with the family at Bromley. There we are here. Elle, Sophie, and Emma.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Your energy level today has been amazing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, what's going on?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Skiing took a lot out of me, Greg.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I mean, I've been wondering. Are you all right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It was negative four that day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't think you're Jesse Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I was feeling the burr up there in Vermont. It's freezing cold. And if you want to look as good as I did up there on the mountain. Go to shop.foxnews.com where you can get all that nice gear. We have a special President's Day Sale 15 percent off. Go check out the hoodie, socks, and T- shirts, and tumblers, and so much more.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Will the real Jesse be back tomorrow?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I thought I was pretty good today, honestly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, you seem very tired.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Just because I'm not talking in the commercial breaks like you maniacs?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Just -- everything is fine.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: OK, just checking. I was just worried.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm running out of gas.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We're worried about you. OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right, let's do this. What is this, animals are great?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Animals are great. Animals are great. Animals are great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right, so this will make you happy. This will make you happy, Jesse. You know why this is a special one, because everybody has a superpower, and even cats have superpowers. For example, this cat can change its size depending on the size of the exit. And so the owner just keeps making it. First, it starts at nine inches.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: That's awesome.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think that's three inches.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh my god.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: That's like rats too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Really, Emily? How would you know that? That's two -- it's two inches. And it's actually -- you know, you get a good scratch when you're doing that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He's trying to make his cat lose weight.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: That's a little harder.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think that's two inches or is that one inch, I'm not sure.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He's pretty good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, there you go. And that is the end.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's a good way to make --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Smart cat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I thought walls work.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I knew there was a catch.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, Emily, you're next.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Oh, great. OK, I wanted to tell you guys about this awesome new brewery in Kannapolis, North Carolina. It was founded and totally owned and ran by veterans. One of the coolest things they had, they just had their grand opening. They have a wall inside where anyone can go inside and buy a beer for any member of a branch of the military, first responders, police etcetera, and then they put it up on the board, and then those guys can come in and get that free beer. We had them on Fox earlier. We're so excited about it. So definitely go and hang out near Charlotte. This Saturday in particular, they're releasing its first-ever charitable beer, the Red Line Ale. All proceeds going to the Kannapolis chapter of the firefighters burned children's fund. If you go anywhere near the area, definitely pop in for a drink or two. Buy one for first responders and our military, and also follow them on social media which I believe is a RealOldArmorBeer on Instagram or wherever you can find them. You can find them on my Twitter page too.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Do you have any samples.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: I wish I did.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I feel like THE FIVE should go there and do a show.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. That sounds like fun.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Right. And all their beer is military-themed names.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I have a feeling they should do a bar like that. And if you want to buy Fox News people drink. That's sounds like a good idea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You're the real hero? You're the real hero?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Donna, you're next.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Once again, Kobe Bryant. Last night the NBA saluted a wonderful basketball player, humanitarian. Grammy Award winner Jennifer Hudson did the great honor of singing this remarkable song. Kobe Bryant will be remembered not just as a great basketball player but also a humanitarian. So God bless your family. God bless all of the other victims of the helicopter crash. Kobe, we miss you already.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Jesse, are you going to recharge tonight?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm going to recharge the battery. I'll be back here tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: My sister says Jesse needs to lay off the Ambien.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Set your DVRs, never miss an episode of "The Five."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Low energy Watters.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
